If the fires get much worse I hope the insurance companies can cover all the losses. It's just that if 1,000 homes are completely destroyed, insurance claims could be in the hundreds of millions.  I don't think most insurance companies could quickly come up with that amount of money and even if they do, it will probably be the last time they would offer policies to any homeowners in those fire-prone areas.  I never thought those fires could reach down into the residential areas in Los Angeles but with the strong winds blowing embers for miles it seems it can happen.  The more area the fire covers, the fire fighters become thinned out.  How many hours can a fire fighter go without rest or sleep while fires keep popping up.  That's a scary scenario that no one is prepared for.
I had wondered why no airdrops were being done but I didn't know they couldn't fly in heavy wind.  They need to drop fire-retardant to stop houses from easily igniting from sparks.  Four major fires all in different areas will be hard to control with limited resources.

Being able to access water quickly is vital. Having sprinklers set up ready before evacuation is what saved our house. Swimming pool and fire pump ready.Start and retreat till ember attack passes. Use face and eye protection. Gloves, leather souled boots, back pack fire spray. Block all vents and door spaces. Steel cover for sky lights. Battery back up for lights. Rake inflammable materials away from walls.  Check for embers after the fire front has gone through. Especially attics and roof spaces. Cheers from Australia.

Fires are chemistry and physics. The pyrotechnic residue from spent fireworks mixed with the ashes and charcoal of the brush sitting in direct sunlight in 90¬∞ F temps for 7 days was enough to trigger a second fire. The ruins of any fire can rekindle if the post fire environment is right for re-ignition. LAFD made the black burnt brush wet, but it dried out, and when it gets dried out from the heat and wind it breaks down and heats up. It‚Äôs called Heat of Decomposition. Remember the primary chemical ingredients in fireworks is gun powder, potassium nitrate, charcoal and sulfur. The mixture of these chemicals become just as flammable and explosive after they dry out as they were before they got wet. Once the dried gunpowder residue becomes hot enough it becomes a highly volatile accelerant that if reignited can worsen fire conditions in a brush fire quickly. All it takes to get the situation right for a rekindle is to raise the temperature of the fuels above Heat of Decomposition (under 300¬∞ F) to the pyrolytic temperature of smoke (above 300¬∞ F).

I'm 83 born and raised in LA.  Since as far back as I remember, my parents loved the going to the beach and driving up and down the Pacific Coast Highway from Santa Monica To Zuma passing thru Malibu.  All those homes and families were already there since I was 4 or 5 years old.  Back then we knew some celebs lived along the beach like Cary Grant, Bing Crosby and Barbara Stanwyck.  We weren't jealous or envious of them.  We had a game trying to guess who lived in which house.  Or who was that washing their car parked in front of their garage?  But we also knew regular people lived there too.  

It was the Rivera of Southern California.  My mom's favorite thing was to have fresh Lobster Tails at one of the great seafood restaurants along the way.  One time we rented horses and rode down Topanga Canyon to the beach just to have lunch.  My parents are gone.  We did this outing frequently over the years into their mid 90's.  Now all that beauty and all those lives, and all that can be seen and experienced by others instantly evaporated by an 75mph firestorm of destruction and destroyed lives.  All thats left are memories ... some heartfelt and some horrific, and some filled with contempt.

[Added January 18, 2025: But back to the winds. As I said, and as you know, everyone on both sides is pushing 100mph Santa Ana winds to explain this, including the weather expert Bill Burr. One problem: there is no such thing. Look it up if you don't believe me. Start with the Beaufort Scale, where you will learn that 100mph winds are normally only found in cyclones, like hurricanes and tornados. Strong Santa Ana winds never hit 100 or even 50. They rarely gust to 40mph, but the ones in LA last week were only about 25. I know because I checked. It is quite easy to do these days, just go to one of the many weather channels and type in the zip code. 25mph is a strong wind, and I guess
 
really stupid people could mistake it for a 100mph wind, supposing they had never been anywhere near a 100mph wind. To give you a comparison, a gale is defined as about 40-45mph, and that can knock you over and cause 25ft waves at sea. A strong gale is 45-55mph, and that can tear shingles off your house. That wasn't happening in LA, because Santa Ana winds never hit strong gale or Beaufort 9. Beaufort 10 is full gale or storm, with winds up to 63mph. As it says at Wiki, this is almost never seen inland, and it will uproot trees and blow houses down. Beaufort 11 is up to 72mph, causing 50ft waves at sea. Even most sailors have never experienced this, and they don't want to. I had stayed up a little bit too late the night before it was also exhausted emotionally from the Palisades fire so I didn't get to watch the Eaton fire as much as I would have liked to especially because I got called into work for early the next day but holy crap it was scary. And then I think the scary star was when I woke up on Wednesday in Burbank and saw smoke from the Eaton fire just blooming over the southern from my home in Burbank. I looked outside the window and the little part of sky I could see was so dark blue I had to ask myself if there was a mountain that I could see out that window but no there wasn't. I stepped out my front door looked to the south and it was the scariest thing I think I've seen in my life and I've seen the beginnings of a tornado. It was something so scary like a severe thunderstorm color clouds in the sky with the sun behind it, looking like absolute hell on earth. It was quite freaked out I said a lot of profanities over the course of the half hour before I left for where I work in downtown Burbank. It got scarier as I went over the bridge that crosses the railroad tracks and the freeway and it was still incredibly windy. And then at work that day, The people who come 7 days a week for breakfast and have the entire 7 months I've worked at this restaurant, We started to get freaked out like if we don't see the regulars we know something's wrong. Luckily we saw the regulars but we did see very few people the rest of the day. It was like the longest 8-hour shift of my life, especially because we had no obstructions and we could see out the windows to the west so not only could we see the Eaton fire smoke looming over us we could also see the Palisades fire about 16 miles in the distance. We stood there and not only did we watch it involve over the day We could actively see the smoke moving. It was hellish and I'm so glad that I wasn't even anywhere near and evacuation zone. I think it was the next day Thursday at work or maybe Friday when everybody got the falls alarm during the Kenneth fire and I freaked out because downtown Burbank is on the other side of the mountains from mandatory evacuation zones from the Eaton fire. It also confused me because I had become aware of the Kenneth fire maybe an hour or two for my shift when it broke out, and I  had driven East to work maybe 15 minutes before and saw nothing on the mountains. [Added January 18, 2025: But back to the winds. As I said, and as you know, everyone on both sides is pushing 100mph Santa Ana winds to explain this, including the weather expert Bill Burr. One problem: there is no such thing. Look it up if you don't believe me. Start with the Beaufort Scale, where you will learn that 100mph winds are normally only found in cyclones, like hurricanes and tornados. Strong Santa Ana winds never hit 100 or even 50. They rarely gust to 40mph, but the ones in LA last week were only about 25. I know because I checked. It is quite easy to do these days, just go to one of the many weather channels and type in the zip code. 25mph is a strong wind, and I guess
 
really stupid people could mistake it for a 100mph wind, supposing they had never been anywhere near a 100mph wind. To give you a comparison, a gale is defined as about 40-45mph, and that can knock you over and cause 25ft waves at sea. A strong gale is 45-55mph, and that can tear shingles off your house. That wasn't happening in LA, because Santa Ana winds never hit strong gale or Beaufort 9. Beaufort 10 is full gale or storm, with winds up to 63mph. As it says at Wiki, this is almost never seen inland, and it will uproot trees and blow houses down. Beaufort 11 is up to 72mph, causing 50ft waves at sea. Even most sailors have never experienced this, and they don't want to.
